awd_titl_txt: BBSRC-NSF/BIO: From atoms to molecules to cells - Multi-scale tools and infrastructure for visualization of annotated 3D structure data
awd_abstract_narration:
This US RCSB Protein Data Bank (RCSB PDB) - UK Protein Data Bank in Europe (PDBe) collaborative project will significantly redesign existing open-source Molstar molecular graphics infrastructure to develop an extensible, one-stop-shop for visualization and interrogation of open-access three-dimensional (3D) structure data integrated from the Protein Data Bank (PDB), NextGen PDB, PDB-Dev, Electron Microscopy Data Bank, Electron Microscopy Image Archive, and BioImage Archive. Molstar works entirely with the users internet browser (e.g., Chrome, Firefox, Safari). It consists of an easy-to-use graphical interface with no user login or software product download, update, or registration required. The redesigned Molstar system will be FAIR (Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, and Reusability) and FACT (Fairness, Accuracy, Confidentiality, Transparency) Principles compliant. It will support efficient data delivery and visualization and study of 3D structure data together with structural, biological, and functional annotations across length scales ranging from individual atoms to whole cells. Researchers, educators, and students accessing the new system will be able to combine, visualize, and evaluate structure data and related biological, medical, and chemical information from multiple open-access data resources. It will also support analyses of 3D structures of biomolecules their respective in organellar or cellular contexts Users of the redesigned Molstar infrastructure will be able to study macromolecular machines (e.g., prokaryotic RNA Polymerase-Ribosome Super Complex; eukaryotic Nuclear Pore Complex) in 3D in situ combined with biological and functional information integrated from a diverse array of open-access biodata resources operating in the Americas, Europe, Oceania, and Asia.

This project will address significant challenges resulting from the growing corpus of 3D structure data stored in disparate open-access primary data resource. These include the need for integration and interoperation of these data with related biological and functional annotations from knowledgebases; the need for a standard data representation for display of 3D structure data across length scales; the need to examine multiple 3D structures of biological macromolecules in groups of related structures coming from cutting-edge techniques such as serial femtosecond X-ray crystallography and cryo-electron microscopy; the need to combine atomic level/multiscale structures with lower resolution information from cryo- electron tomography and super-resolution microscopy; and the need for efficient data packaging, compression, and delivery for users with diverse levels of internet connectivity. The project will overcome current limitations in data management, interoperability, and visualization that make it difficult, sometimes impossible, for molecular, cellular, and organismal biologists to fully utilize the world’s open-access 3D biostructure data. The software products of the project will be freely accessible at https://www.molstar.org. Utilization of the Molstar software will be exemplified within the web portals of RCSB PDB (https://www.rcsb.org) and PDBe (https://www.pdbe.org), which are available to all users at no charge and with no limitations on data usage under the most permissive Creative Commons CC0 1.0 Universal license (https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PDB is the single global repository for three-dimensional (3D) atomic structures of macromolecules determined experimentally. Established in 1971, it is the first open access digital resource in all of biological sciences and currently houses over 228,000 structures of macromolecules and their complexes. RCSB PDB’s research-focused web portal (RCSB.org) provides a wide variety of tools and features to explore 3D structure data archived in the PDB, enriched with evolutionary and functional annotations integrated from trusted external data resources. Additionally, RCSB.org provides access to over one million computed structure models (CSMs) from the AlphaFold Protein Structure Database (alphafold.ebi.ac.uk) and ModelArchive (modelarchive.org), providing expanded coverage of structural biology data to researchers, educators, students, and other scientific professionals worldwide.  

 

One of the primary methods for interacting with 3D structure data is through molecular graphics viewers such as Molstar (molstar.org), which is a web-based software for visualization and analysis of molecules. The NSF-funded Molstar Project has made significant strides in enhancing the accessibility, usability, and integration of structural biology data. As part of the RCSB PDB’s ongoing efforts to support molecular visualization and data interoperability, the project has focused on expanding and refining the Molstar 3D visualization infrastructure and related tools to enable more seamless exploration of biomolecular data across a wide range of scales.

 

The key outcome of this project has been the development of the MolViewSpec toolkit (molstar.org/mol-view-spec/), which offers standardized data libraries, view specifications, and composition modules for creating reproducible visual scenes of molecules, shareable across software applications. MolVIewSpec adopts a declarative data-driven approach to describe, load, render, and visually deliver molecular structures, along with 3D representations, coloring schemes, and associated structural, biological, or functional annotations. These advancements allow for efficient data delivery and web-native visualization of multiscale biological structures, enabling users to interrogate data ranging from individual atoms to entire cells. The toolkit includes both a Python composition module (available via PyPI and GitHub) and a web component for managing annotation data, which are integrated into the existing Molstar GitHub repository (github.com/molstar). Furthermore, the project improved the RCSB PDB’s data and annotation server, data.rcsb.org, by incorporating new data types such as disease annotations from Pharos, structural classifications from InterPro, and information on antibiotic resistance from the Comprehensive Antibiotic Resistance Database (CARD). These new annotations are now available via the RCSB.org website and Data API. 

 

In addition to creating MolVIewSpec and improving data accessibility, the project has led to the standardization of visualization protocols using Molstar on RCSB.org. A dedicated visualizer has been developed to enhance the examination of small molecules and their interactions with proteins and nucleic acids. Another new feature in Molstar streamlines the visualization of protein-small molecule interactions in PDB structures and associated experimental data. These developments provide a unified and consistent experience for users when visualizing all types of biomolecular data and enable improved quality checks during the PDB biocuration process.

 

Importantly, the project has contributed to the adoption of the FAIR and FACT principles for data sharing, ensuring that the data and visualizations are findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable. This commitment is reflected not only in the improved open-source Molstar framework but also in the integration of this infrastructure with external databases and resources, such as interoperability with the PDB-IHM portal (pdb-ihm.org) for disseminating structures determined using integrative and hybrid modeling methods and, in the long term, visualization tools like ChimeraX (www.cgl.ucsf.edu/chimerax/). These collaborations also raised awareness for our work with other educational and research initiatives, such as Proteopedia (proteopedia.org), further expanding its impact. The project has received notable recognition within the scientific community, with key findings and software developments being disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, including a paper in Current Protocols (2024) detailing the MolViewSpec toolkit. The project’s influence is also evidenced by the significant uptake of Molstar’s infrastructure by the broader research community, with over 248 open-source projects now building on Molstar’s framework.

 

Looking forward, the Molstar and MolViewSpec projects will continue to play a critical role in advancing the visualization of molecular and cellular structures. These tools support a wide variety of scientific disciplines, from structural biology and biochemistry to drug discovery and molecular pharmacology, providing an invaluable resource for researchers, educators, and students alike. With continued collaboration and a growing user base, the project is poised to facilitate even greater integration and analysis of biological data, driving future breakthroughs in our understanding of complex molecular systems.


 

 


Last Modified: 02/11/2025
Modified by: Stephen K Burley

The projects influence is also evidenced by the significant uptake of Molstars infrastructure by the broader research community, with over 248 open-source projects now building on Molstars framework.

These tools support a wide variety of scientific disciplines, from structural biology and biochemistry to drug discovery and molecular pharmacology, providing an invaluable resource for researchers, educators, and students alike. With continued collaboration and a growing user base, the project is poised to facilitate even greater integration and analysis of biological data, driving future breakthroughs in our understanding of complex molecular systems.
